name: libyamlpp
description: Alex's libyamlpp
readme:
0  QUICKSTART

libyaml++ is a C++ library for reading and writing YAML streams.  To build,
run from your Linux command shell:

 ~$ tar xzf libyamlpp.tar.gz
 ~$ cd libyamlpp
 libyamlpp$ ./build.sh

Next, see USING LIBYAML++ for sample code.


1  INTRODUCTION

libyaml++ is a C++ library for reading and writing YAML streams.  YAML stands
for YAML Ain't a Markup Language.  It is a portable data-serialization
protocol, designed primarily for readability by humans.  YAML plays well as a
protocol for message-based distributed processing systems.

YAML is somewhat comparable with XML in that it can be used as a protocol for
serializing structured, hierarchical documents.  XML, however, was designed to
be backwards-compatible with SGML, the Standard Generalized Markup Language,
which in turn was designed primarily to store structured documents.  YAML
therefore has more freedom of design.  When compared to XML, YAML elevates
its design goals to support data streams that show a balance between a
flexible syntax and readability.


2  DIRECTORY TREE STRUCTURE

This distribution consists of three components.  The first and most important
component is the library's source code, and it is placed under the src/
subdirectory.  The second component is the demo application, which demonstrates
the library's capabilities and use and is located, obviously enough, in the
demo/ subdirectory.  The last component is the testing code, which tests the
source code of the library and is located in the test/ subdirectory.


3  BUILDING

The The easiest way to build libyaml++ is using the build.sh script in the
distribution's root directory.  It will set up your system for building
libyaml++ as well as its unit-tests.  The build.sh script assumes you are using
Linux tough.  An alternative way is to build the library manually.  If you
intened to hack on the code we recommend you set yourself up properly:  install
Boost.BuildV2 and GoogleTest in a convenient directory in your system and use
bjam for the build.

We will cover in this section all approaches mentioned above.


3.1  BUILDING USING BUILD.SH

From the command prompt of your Linux box run:

 ~$ cd libyamlpp
 libyamlpp$ ./build.sh

The build.sh script can take any target as a command-line parameter, so you may
for example run

 libyamlpp$ ./build.sh demo check

to build the demo and check targets, for the demonstration application and
unit-tests, repectively.  The build.sh script can also take a special
command-line argument, wipeclean, which will wipe clean any files and
directories it may have created:

 libyamlpp$ ./build.sh wipeclean

The above command will leave nothing but the original libyaml++ distribution
has.  Make sure you pass no other command-line argument when running the above
command.


3.2  USING BOOST.BUILD

Boost.Build doesn't usually come by default in an operating-system's install.
So first, make sure you have Boost.BuildV2, and Boost.Jam on which Boost.Build
depends, installed.  Once that is set up, running the build is a matter of a
single command.


3.2.1  SETTING-UP BOOST.BUILD

If you run a Debian-based Linux distribution, this may simply be a matter of

 #$ sudo apt-get install boost-build

Other Linux distributions have their own package management system, so read the
appropriate manual pages.  If that fails or if you don't have a package
management system, get Boost.Build from
http://www.boost.org/doc/tools/build/index.html and following the instructions
at http://www.boost.org/doc/tools/build/doc/html/bbv2/installation.html.
Installing Boost.Build is a fairly straightforward procedure that consists
mainly of four steps:

 1. Copy the extracted Boost.Build distribution into a directory reachable by
    your operating-system's PATH.
 2. Configure Boost.Build by choosing your compiler of choice in the
    site-config.jam file in Boost.Build's root directory.  It should be a
    matter of uncommenting a line such as

    using gcc ;

 3. Copy the bjam binary into a directory reachable by your operating-system's
    PATH.
 4. export BOOST_BUILD_PATH=/path/to/boost-build

Further details are given in the link above.


3.2.2  BUILDING USING BOOST.BUILD

To build libyaml++, from the libyaml++ distribution's root directory run the
command:

 libyamlpp$ bjam release

This will build libyaml++ and place the resultant binary in a directory
structure under src/bin/release/.  The exact heirarchy structure will depend on
your system.  Our system, for example, will place the resultant binary in
src/bin/release/gcc/libyaml++.so.  Your environment may be, for example, in
src/bin/release/msvc/libyaml++.so.

To build the demo application, run the following command from the project
distribution's root directory:

 libyamlpp$ bjam demo release

Again, the exact location of the resultant binary will depend on your system
but will be somewhere under demo/bin/release/.  In our case it is in
demo/bin/release/gcc/libyaml++-demo.

To build the test suites, run

 libyamlpp$ bjam check

This will also run the tests once they are built.


3.3  TESTING

The source code comes with a set of tests that attempt to find bugs or issues
with the library.  These tests rely on the Google Test framework, so you must
have that set up to run them.


3.3.1  SETTING-UP GOOGLETEST

Get GoogleTest from http://code.google.com/p/googletest/.  We used GoogleTest
v1.1.0 successfully.  Extract the distribution package in a directory of your
choice, and build it.  To install GoogleTest in your home directory on a Unix
machine the following commands will do:

 ~$ tar jxf gtest-1.1.0.tar.bz2
 ~$ cd gtest-1.1.0
 gtest-1.1.0$ ./configure --prefix=$HOME/usr
 gtest-1.1.0$ make
 gtest-1.1.0$ make install

Next, you must make sure that

 a. the C++ preprocessor can find the gtest headers
 b. the linker can find the gtest library when linking the libyaml++ tests
 c. the runtime evironment can find the shared library when the tests are run

To accomodate for this on a Unix platform using gcc for the build and assuming
the above commands were used for installing GoogleTest, add the following three
environment variables to your shell's startup file, such as ~/.bashrc:

 export CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH=$HOME/usr/include:$CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH
 export LIBRARY_PATH=$HOME/usr/lib:$LIBRARY_PATH
 export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=$HOME/usr/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH


3.3.2  RUNNING THE TESTS

Once GoogleTest is set up you may run the tests.  From the commandline and from
within the project's root directory, run:

 libyamlpp$ bjam check


4  USING LIBYAML++

[ NOTE:  as our library is not fully implemented yet, the following section
describes what is being constantly changed.  Thus, when we describe how our
yet-to-be-born library is used either the text is hypothetical or is outdated
and needs to be revised. ]

To use libyaml++, you need either a C++ compiler or to know how to write one.
We recommed the former.  Put the binaries somewhere reachable by your compiler
and linker's search paths.

 #include <fstream>
 #include <algorithm>
 #include <tr1/memory>
 #include <yaml++.h>

 using namespace std;
 using namespace std::tr1;

 void play_with_node(shared_ptr<node> nd) { }

 shared_ptr<node> return_some_node() { }

 int main(int argc, char* argv)
 {
     // to read yaml and do something with it:
     ifstream the_file("/home/me/teh_file.yaml");

     // NOTE:  The following are hypothetical ideas, as none of this is not
     //        implemented yet.  We have two solutions in mind.  The first:
     for_each(istream_iterator<yaml::node>(the_file),
              istream_iterator<yaml::node>(),
              play_with_node);

     // the second hypothetical solution is:
     shard_ptr<yaml::node> data = yaml::load(the_file); // loads an istream
     for_each(data.begin(), data.end(), play_with_node);

     // do stuff with data

     shared_ptr<node> my_data;
     generate_n(back_inserter(my_data), 42, return_some_node);
     cout << yaml::dump(my_data);  // dumps a string
 }

commit.message: Merge branch 'mtm'
build.sh:  restore_wd before exit

Merge branch 'master' into build_doc

Conflicts:

	build.sh

generate report using build.sh

run ./build.sh docs

doc, docs, document, documents, documentation are all synonyms.

Typesets any *.tex files under /doc.

build.sh:  use pushd, not cd

then i can popd all dirs to reach original wd.

Merge branch 'team_report' into build_doc

Conflicts:

	doc/wscript

fix:  download gtest and boost.build for user

used to be downloaded into /tmp, and thus when two users shared the same
machine build.sh would find the downloaded file, which might have been
downloaded by the other user and the permissions set wouldn't allow
reading.  the build would then fail with permission denied.

now download into $INSTALL_DIR, which is a directory created by mktemp
thus the chance for this permissions issue hapenning is reduced to
minimum.
proof-read, enhancements and typos

Wrote team report

Wrote with it with Matan.  Almost complete!
Merge branch 'mtm'

handle "configuration file syntax errros"

this obviously might not work, but it's just for the sake of
demonstration.  the check relies on mapping every string or integer
event to the next.  it works for mappings, but in the case of a sequence
it will still map every two elements of the sequence as key-value pairs,
and report an error if there is an odd number of elements.  similarly,
if the document consists of a single scalar an error will be emitted
(althought that might actually be more reasonable).

allow input from stdin in configuration demo

if configuration demo is invoked with no command-line argument or with
argument "-", input is taken from stdin.  Otherwise the first
command-line argument is taken as the name of the file to open for
parsing.

This implies I had to take off the usage message.  Instead, I placed it
in the source file.  I think this is fine because the whole point of
this is demonstrating libyaml++, so the source file will be read anyhow.
fixed typo in usage message of configuration demo
added configuration parsing demo.

demo/ will hold other demos as well

moved demo/demo.cc into demo/begin/demo.cc.  we can then create other
subdirectories under demo/ for other demos.
fix:  parse eos once, not after each document.
support multiple documents in a stream
Merge branch 'mtm'

demo:  be more unixy, not interactive

it is easy to wrap the binary with a shell loop if desired.  but if the
application is interactive then it isn't very useable in a pipe.
specifically, in the state it was prior to this patch cin would clear()
after each iteration, thus rendering an infinite loop when stdin doesn't
come from a tty.  also, the application would print out a useless
greeting message when stdin isn't connected to a tty.
renamed demo source file

fix:  lex string starting with number as string

this fixes a bug in which whenever a token was started with a digit it
was automatically assumed that a number is being lexed.  this is a bug
because

 42 meters

is a string, not a number.
parser:  parse_eos() expects eos
added doxygen comments to code

load(), parser ctor:  removed ptr overload

it's safer to use smart-ptr overload only.

changed demo to use load(), and be interactive

made the demo application slightly more interesting by parsing input
from stdin rather than a compiled-in literal.

also, the demo uses load(), thus demonstrating a more elegant code.

also, added comments to source code.

added load() and <iyaml++.hh>

load() is a wrapper function for parsing.  instead of instantiating
yaml::syn::parser() directly and then calling its parse() member
function, use yaml::load().  load() takes the same parameters the
parser's ctor takes.

added ctor to parser:  take shared_ptr of handler

an overload to the ctor that takes a primitive pointer for the handler
removed redundant includes
wrote a simple demo application.
test_parser:  include parser from src

added a test of mixed seq, map, ints, strs

like a wild west movie, shooting in all directions ...

parser:  allow integers when strings are allowed

this is mostly a hack, as I assume token::INTEGER holds a string as its
value, and I use string_node to represent the node.  thus, from the
representation perspective, there is no difference between a string and
an integer.  it might actually be a Good Thing in a broad sense, but the
scalar node's name should probably be different from string_node, and I
should be able to extract an integer out of an integer scalar (for that
matter, or an object T out of a scalar, if and when I support tags).
Merge branch 'master' into parse
update value when scanning integer
added two more tests to parser

added alternative approach to usage in README

for lexical analysis

for syntactical analysis.

i replaced those files with *_node files, committed previously.
construct syntax tree
Merge branch 'master' into parse

compacted grammar by using regex

sometimes using regular expressions adds clarity and makes the grammar
more fluent.

removed whitespace specs from grammar

whenever whitespace rules are obvious or it is not nesccesary to specify
them then specifying whitespace is just noise.  it does more damage than
good, as it turns out, when i write the parser and try to follow the
grammar.
added yaml grammar file of what i implement
updated install_dir comment in .build conf file

in parse_document(), return after eos

fix:  shared_ptr is in header tr1/memory

initial commit of parser
fix:  build.sh regex error in parsing conf file

build.sh:  install directory is unique

use mktemp for this.  store value in a configuration file, .build, so
later builds know where to find the installed files.

build.sh:  fix BOOST_BUILD_PATH issue

only set BOOST_BUILD_PATH if bjam isn't installed system-wide.  if bjam
is installed system-wide then boost.build probably wasn't installed by
build.sh, and so setting BOOST_BUILD_PATH would misconfigure
boost.build, pointing to the wrong directory.

lex for token::DOCUMENT_BEGIN

Must be "---" followed by whitespace.  The following have DOCUMENT_BEGIN
in them:

---
hello, world

--- hello, world

However the following have no DOCUMENT_BEGIN in them but are plain
scalar strings that include "---" in the string:

---hello, world

---

(a document that has nothing other than "---", not even a single space
or a single newline after the last "-" character).

when lexing strings, store the string value

in token, store value s.t.:

token.tag == token::STRING
token.value == "the string value"
refactored scanner tests into test fixtures
added UNDEFINED token, for an undefined token
use implicit ctor for tokens
fix warning:  wrap &&, || with parens
fix:  lex multiple pairs in a flow mapping
sip() after lexing separators

support lexing nested sequences and mappings

flow sequences and flow mappings, that is.
fix:  mapping pairs

fix:  lex sequence elements

a sequence element separator is a comma followed by a space.  the
following:

 a, b

is a string and should be lexed as such.  however, the following:

 [a, b]

is a sequence, and should be lexed as such.  therefore, we have to keep
track of sequence_begin tokens we see, to know if a ", " denotes an
element separator or just part of a string.
ut++2gt.sh isn't necessary anymore

fix:  remove log file

succ logs.  clean logfile after any call to fail or succ.
fixed BOOST_BUILD_PATH env var setting

there's nothing interesting in the log anyway.

removed redundant logging.

unnecessary, and uses color escapes too.
build.sh:  shell quoting

added a wipeclean target to build.sh

this will wipe out everything this script may have created, but will
leave the log file.  a message about the logfile hanging around is
presented to the user though.

no such thing as "initial build".

to build, just run ./build.sh.  the removes the complexity of initially
running buils.sh and then setting up environment and from then on using
bjam.

not using gtest dir;  rm it and ignore it

check against the gtest.h header instead

build.sh overhaul ...

added support for gtest (download, install, set up)
added cleanup procedure:  on a trap, on fail
added user instructions messages before and after build
download stuff to /tmp
install into /tmp/libyamlpp.XXXXXXXXXX
added success/failure messages to buid.sh
removed redundant grep in build.sh
misplaced echo line in build.sh script

added a one-command build script

build.sh grabs Boost.Build, sets it up and finally builds the project.
the script builds the library as well as the demo application, and it
also performs unit tests.
use implicit token ctor call
we don't do styles ... yet.
added tests for unquoted string, pair and seq

scan:  adding lexing for unquoted strings

i can lex now for

hi    which translates to <str:hi> <eos>
a:b   which translates to <str:a:b> <eos>
a: b  which translates to <str:a> <pair_sep> <str:b> <eos>
a,b   which translates to <str:a,b> <eos>
a, b  which translates to <str:a> <seq_sep> <str:b> <eos>

The last one is a problematic though, because it should be one string.
i don't know if i should find a way to fix it or let the parser handle
this situation...
removed redundant check for eof in scan

if sip() meets eof, peek will be set to -1.

i expect -1 to be control character, one that is not likely to be in a
YAML stream.  this way, i can check for peek == -1, and then if it is
check for !is to confirm eof.  or something.

added scanner::putback():  put peek back to buf

scanner::putback() puts current peek back to the input buffer and then
updates peek, effectively restoring peek to the state prior to the
previous sip().

broke "composite" tests back into 2 tests

this way i can use CHECK_EQ, which gives better failure messages.

also, changed sequences from vectors to list, because it might be faster
this way.  yes, i know we're talking about containers of 2-3 elements.
:p
added tests for : , and quoted string
commented out unimplemented tokens
added a test for parsing a few tokens

Remove tools subdir.

No longer needed, this was UnitTest++ plumbing and it no longer needed
with Gtest.

refactored ScanMappingBeginEnd test

collapsed two tests (EXPECTs) into one.

well i still kinda have two tests in there, but it's slightly better
because the tests are more related to each other:  check for equal size
of two containers and that elements in container one are in container
two.

added operator==() to token class

for now, using it in test code.
added descriptive comment to ut++2gt.sh

Added gtest/ to #includes so no need to -I gtest

more portable this way.  gtest/ is a directory somewhere in the include
path, so i just specify to look in $INCLUDE_PATH/gtest rather than
hardcoding the path in the build system.
added tests for number lexing

each branch in scan() returns

as opposed to set the return value which will ultimately be returned.

the reason is that in the previous approach i had to use if-else-if so
that when a branch is entered no other branch will be entered.  but as
it turns out sometimes i can enter a branch and then change my mind
and let other branches have a chance to catch the condition.

for example, if i scan a '-' it may be a start of a negative number, or
it may be a document-begin, etc.  i need to get into a branch, and then
decide if i should give another branch a chance (by restoring the input
first of course).

newline, should parse to [null], an array with a null element.  so, the

various tokens depending on the previous token...

Removed --debug option from waf configure

waf provides -d DEBUG_LEVEL for the C++ compiler, so our --debug is
redundant and confusing.  Furthermore, the -d option actually accepts a
parameter: ultradebug, debug, release or optimized.  It's thus more
powerful (albeit perhaps less flexible as we have no control over its
behavior).

We'll use this for demonstrating our library.  We might as well use it
for development purposes, as a playground.  waf is configured to build
our project as a library, not an executable, so by having a demo area we
can actually build an executable we can build and run and test.

string scalars can span across multiple lines

This just in:  string scalars can span across multiple lines!  Newlines
in string scalars are never significant, though, and any newline is
always folded into a single space character.  This as per section 2.3 of
the standard.

You may ask what is the different between scalars and literal style or
folded style, then.  For what I understand, literal style's newlines are
always significant, and folded style's newlines are significant only
when ending empty or whitespace-only lines.  This as opposed to string
scalars' newlines, which are never significant and thus are always
folded into (replaced by) a single space.  Newlines that are significant
aren't folded.

Added git-issues to our repo.

git-issues is a distributed issue-tracking script.  It creates a branch
named "issues" and stores in it its issue-tracking database.  If the
script is checked into the project, as I'm doing right now, then users
can share this script and thus share and track together bugs.

See the README file inside .gitissues for some usage details.

See the git-issues project page,
http://github.com/jwiegley/git-issues/tree/master for more details about
git-issues.

name: rul
description: A XULRunner generator written in Ruby.
readme:
This is my RUL app
==================

RUL is an open-source XUL Runner framework. It helps you build a XUL Runner application by:

* auto-generating your application files
* providing utility tasks in rake to build and install your app

Instructions
============
1) git clone git://github.com/tiegz/rul.git rul
2) cd rul
3) rake app:new
4) rake app:install:mac (only works on Mac so far)
5) Open the Mac bundle from your /Applications directory to test

NOTE
====
This is totally experimental and the structure will probably change as I learn more about XULRunner 
and packaging XULRunner applications

name: gettext_to_i18n
description: Transforms gettext to I18n API and generate SimpleBackend locale file
readme:
GettextToI18n
=============

This plugin will convert your complete Rails project from Gettext calls to the new i18n api calls introduced in Rails 2.2.2. NB: This plugin is higly experimental, so before running, BACKUP YOUR CODE. It will touch your code and things always can go wrong!


Example
=======
	<%=_("Some string that will be translated, into %{lan}" % {:lan => 'english'}) %>

will be converted into:

	<%=t(:message_0, :lan => 'english', :scope => [:controller, :controller_name]) %>

it will then place a entry:
	
	"Some string that will be translated, into {{lan}}"
	
in the standard.yml locale file it generates.


About namespaces
========
By default the plugin walks all files in the app directory. It places the message id's into namespaces. The namespace are divided like this: 

	Controllers: translation[:txt][:controller][:controller_name]
	Views: translation[:txt][:view][:view_colleciton_name]
	-> etc.
	
	

Usage
=======
To convert all your views, controllers and models to the new format.

	rake gettext_to_i18n:transform


Installation
=======
./script/plugin install git://github.com/japetheape/gettext_to_i18n.git



-------------
Copyright (c) 2008 Jaap van der Meer, released under the MIT license
